articles.title: Cake to the rescue: how these PhD students are cooking up a sense of community
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 21 October 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02948-2One treat at a time, these graduate students are helping to raise funds for charitable organizations.
articles.content:
A bake sale at the University of British Columbia. Credit: Amirhossein Rashidi (AHR shots)

When the National Astronomy Meeting, organized by the UK Royal Astronomical Society, descended on Durham University in July, Martina Veresvarska saw the gathering as an opportunity not just to talk shop, but also to indulge her baking hobby. The annual conference, usually held in the British Isles, is one of the largest of its kind in Europe.

Veresvarska is a PhD candidate at the UK university’s Centre for Extragalactic Astronomy and a co-founder of the astronomy department’s charity bake-sale organization, Cakes for Good. At this year’s conference, Veresvarska and fellow astronomy PhD student Ciera Sargent ran their largest bake sale so far, helped by ten volunteer bakers from the department. During an organized coffee break at the meeting, the team catered for nearly 1,000 attendees and raised roughly £450 (a little over US$600) in just 30 minutes for the Great North Air Ambulance Service.

Cakes for Good is just one example of scientists coming together not only to foster community in their own departments, but also to raise money for charitable causes. For some, these efforts represent a small but powerful way to make a difference in their communities when their busy schedules or financial situations might otherwise prevent it.

Building community

Veresvarska arrived at Durham as a new PhD student in September 2021, amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Making connections with other students or faculty members proved difficult, even after lockdowns began to lift and the world started to open up again, she says.

To help rebuild a sense of community in the department, Veresvarska and her co-founders started Cakes for Good in April 2022. Instead of baking for the department and accepting money to cover the cost of ingredients, as had been done in the past, the Cakes for Good team decided to donate any money raised to charity.

“We thought that letting others [in the department] decide what charities this should go to might be a good way to get people involved and interested,” Veresvarska says.

Cakes for Good ran its first charity bake sale in May 2022 to support humanitarian aid in Ukraine. Since then, it has run monthly bake sales throughout the academic year to support global causes such as Medical Aid for Palestinians and support for schoolgirls in rural Kenya. It has also donated money from the sales to local charities supporting transgender youth, refugees and asylum seekers and environmental conservation. Each sale earns about £180–200, and Cakes for Good has raised roughly £4,555 for charity since 2022.

Cakes for Good bake sales organized by astronomers at Durham University, UK, have raised thousands of pounds for range of charities.Credit: Cakes for Good

Anything chocolate is usually a big seller, Veresvarska says. The only complaint has been that some of the baked goods are just too good, she jokes, adding: “I had someone tell me in January that it’s unfair that we hold the bake sale outside their door, because they’re on a diet.”

Working to develop community is also at the heart of a biannual bake sale run by the Chemistry Graduate Students Society (CGSS) at the University of Waterloo in Ontario, Canada, in collaboration with undergraduate chemistry clubs. Its first bake sale, in 2023, raised funds during Pride Month for a local organization, Spectrum, that offers a gathering place, as well as mental-health resources, for the LGBTQ+ community.

Of the society’s two bake sales each year, the first raises funds for Spectrum, the second for another local charity, such as the Women’s Crisis Services of Waterloo Region. The organizers say that, at each event, they raise roughly Can$500–800 (US$360–580). Cookies — chocolate chip, matcha or snickerdoodle, which are rolled with cinnamon and sugar before baking — are usually a big hit (see ‘University of Waterloo’s idiot-proof cookies for scientists’), along with loaf cakes such as banana bread, says Madison Donohoe, a PhD student and co-president of the CGSS.

At the University of British Columbia (UBC) in Vancouver, Canada, the CGSS runs a charity bake sale three times a year. For an entrance fee of just Can$2, staff, faculty members and students in the department can take as many baked goods as they like, usually from a selection of up to ten options.

Lucas Andrew, a chemistry PhD student and CGSS president at the UBC, says that queues often form about 20 minutes before the charity bakes appear. Recent treats have included matcha cheesecake and butter mochi, a cake made with coconut milk and glutinous rice flour that originated in Hawaii. At each event, the group raises Can$100–200 for local charities. Among these are the PHS Community Services Society, which provides housing and health-care services to vulnerable people in Vancouver, and RAVEN, which supports local Indigenous communities.

Chemistry graduates at the University of British Columbia in Canada run charity bake sales three times a year.Credit: Amirhossein Rashidi (AHR shots)

“As grad students, we don’t generally have a lot of disposable income,” Andrew says. “You may not be able to often donate on your own to a charity, but the fact that we can come together as this community and contribute to these local initiatives is really, really nice.”

Tips for success

If you’d like to start your own charity bake sale, these bakers have some words of wisdom to share.

Go where the people are. Attract customers by hosting bake sales at busy times and locations. For the University of Waterloo’s bake sale, this means between 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. in the atrium of the Science Teaching Complex, where a lot of hungry students will be on a break from class, says Emily Wedde, co-president of the CGSS.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a positive community initiative where graduate students organize charity bake sales to raise funds for diverse humanitarian and local causes. This effort fosters community spirit, supports multiple charities with tangible donations, and encourages collective action among students who may have limited individual resources. The impact is meaningful and broad, benefiting various vulnerable groups and promoting social good within academic environments.
articles.personality_title: Graduate students unite to raise charity funds through bake sales
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Graduate students often have busy schedules and limited money, making it hard to get involved in charity work. During the COVID-19 pandemic, many found it even harder to connect with others in their departments.

**What happened** – PhD students at several universities, including Durham University in the UK, the University of Waterloo in Canada, and the University of British Columbia in Canada, started organizing charity bake sales. These events offer homemade treats like cookies, cakes, and cheesecakes to raise money for different charities. For example, at Durham University’s National Astronomy Meeting in July 2025, students raised over £450 (around US$600) in just 30 minutes. Since 2022, Durham’s group, Cakes for Good, has raised more than £4,500 for causes like humanitarian aid in Ukraine and support for transgender youth.

**Impact** – These bake sales bring students together to build community and support important causes. They raise money for a wide range of charities, including those helping refugees, supporting LGBTQ+ communities, and protecting the environment. The events also create chances for students to connect, especially after pandemic isolation. By pooling their efforts, students who might not have much spare money can still make a difference.

**What's next step** – The student groups plan to continue holding regular bake sales during the academic year, choosing new charities to support each time. They also share tips, like picking busy locations and times to attract more people. This approach could inspire other universities or departments to start similar community events.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Graduate students are combining their baking skills and community spirit to raise thousands of dollars for charity while strengthening connections in their academic departments.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des doctorants unissent leurs forces pour collecter des fonds caritatifs grâce à des ventes de gâteaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les doctorants ont souvent un emploi du temps chargé et peu d'argent, ce qui rend difficile leur engagement dans des actions caritatives. La pandémie de COVID-19 a encore compliqué les liens sociaux au sein des départements.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des doctorants de plusieurs universités, dont l’Université de Durham au Royaume-Uni, l’Université de Waterloo et l’Université de la Colombie-Britannique au Canada, ont commencé à organiser des ventes de gâteaux au profit d’associations caritatives. Ces événements proposent des pâtisseries maison comme des cookies, des gâteaux et des cheesecakes pour récolter des fonds. Par exemple, lors de la réunion nationale d’astronomie de Durham en juillet 2025, ils ont collecté plus de 450 £ (environ 600 $ US) en seulement 30 minutes. Depuis 2022, le groupe Cakes for Good de Durham a récolté plus de 4 500 £ pour des causes comme l’aide humanitaire en Ukraine et le soutien aux jeunes transgenres.

**Impact** – Ces ventes de gâteaux permettent aux étudiants de se rassembler pour créer du lien social et soutenir des causes importantes. Ils collectent des fonds pour diverses associations aidant les réfugiés, soutenant les communautés LGBTQ+ ou protégeant l’environnement. Ces événements offrent aussi des occasions de rencontres, surtout après la période d’isolement liée à la pandémie. En unissant leurs forces, des étudiants avec peu de moyens peuvent tout de même agir.

**Prochaine étape** – Ces groupes d’étudiants prévoient de continuer à organiser des ventes de gâteaux régulières pendant l’année universitaire, en choisissant à chaque fois de nouvelles associations à soutenir. Ils partagent aussi des conseils, comme choisir des lieux et horaires fréquentés pour attirer plus de monde. Cette initiative pourrait encourager d’autres universités à lancer des événements similaires.

**Phrase clé** – Des doctorants allient leurs talents culinaires et leur esprit de communauté pour collecter des milliers de dollars pour des associations tout en renforçant les liens dans leurs départements universitaires.
articles.personality_title_es: Estudiantes de posgrado se unen para recaudar fondos benéficos con ventas de pasteles
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los estudiantes de posgrado suelen tener horarios ocupados y poco dinero, lo que dificulta su participación en actividades benéficas. La pandemia de COVID-19 también hizo más difícil conectar con sus compañeros.

**Qué pasó** – Estudiantes de doctorado en varias universidades, como la Universidad de Durham en el Reino Unido, y las universidades de Waterloo y Columbia Británica en Canadá, comenzaron a organizar ventas de pasteles para recaudar dinero para organizaciones benéficas. Estos eventos ofrecen postres caseros como galletas, pasteles y cheesecakes. Por ejemplo, en la reunión nacional de astronomía en Durham en julio de 2025, recaudaron más de £450 (unos 600 dólares) en solo 30 minutos. Desde 2022, el grupo Cakes for Good de Durham ha recogido más de £4,500 para causas como ayuda humanitaria en Ucrania y apoyo a jóvenes transgénero.

**Impacto** – Estas ventas de pasteles ayudan a los estudiantes a unirse, crear comunidad y apoyar causas importantes. Recaudan fondos para diversas organizaciones que ayudan a refugiados, apoyan a la comunidad LGBTQ+ y protegen el medio ambiente. También ofrecen oportunidades para que los estudiantes se conecten, especialmente después del aislamiento por la pandemia. Al unir sus esfuerzos, estudiantes con pocos recursos pueden hacer una diferencia.

**Próximo paso** – Los grupos estudiantiles planean seguir realizando ventas de pasteles regularmente durante el año académico, eligiendo nuevas organizaciones para apoyar en cada ocasión. También comparten consejos, como elegir lugares y horarios concurridos para atraer más gente. Esta idea podría inspirar a otras universidades a crear eventos similares.

**Frase clave** – Estudiantes de posgrado combinan sus habilidades para hornear y su espíritu comunitario para recaudar miles de dólares para organizaciones benéficas mientras fortalecen sus lazos académicos.
